title-group.article-title: An experimental investigation of exhaust emissions of a 1999 Cummins ISM370 diesel engine supplemented with H2

article-meta.aff: 1West Virginia University, Morgantown, West Virginia, USA
2Houston Advanced Research Center, Woodlands, Texas, USA

author-notes.corresp: *West Virginia University, Morgantown, West Virginia 26506, USA. email: hailin.li@mail.wvu.edu

abstract.p: This paper investigates the effect of hydrogen (H2) addition on the exhaust emissions of a 1999 Cummins ISM370 heavy-duty diesel engine with H2 continuously supplemented to intake air. Using the 13-mode European Stationary Cycle (ESC), the addition of 2 per cent H2 by volume increased the emissions of oxides of nitrogen (NOx) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), but reduced nitric oxide (NO) emissions. The addition of 4 per cent H2 increased the emissions of NO, NO2, and NOx. When examined under constant load, the addition of H2 reduced the emissions of particulate matter (PM) and carbon monoxide (CO), but had very mild effects on hydrocarbon (HC) emissions. It was also shown that the reduction in PM emissions was due to the reduced diesel fuel flowrate rather than the improvement to the combustion efficiency of diesel fuel. However, the addition of a relatively large amount of H2 at medium to high (30–70 per cent) load substantially increased the emissions of NOx. This was due to an increase in maximum local combustion temperature resulting from the enhanced heat release rate, advanced combustion phasing, and reduced combustion duration. In comparison, the addition of a small amount of H2 had a very mild effect on NOx emissions. However, a substantial reduction in NOx emissions was observed with the addition of large amounts of H2 at 10–15 per cent load, which was due to deteriorated peak heat release rate observed at premixed combustion process and elongated diffusion combustion process, which reduced the peak local combustion temperature and retarded the combustion phasing. It was also noted that the addition of H2 substantially increased the emissions of NO2, indicating the significant effect of H2 addition in enhancing the conversion of NO to NO2. When measured using the 13-mode ESC, the addition of 2 per cent and 4 per cent H2 increased NO2 emissions by 300 per cent and 221 per cent, respectively. When measured under constant load, a maximum NO2/NOx ratio of 62.2 per cent was obtained with the addition of 4 per cent H2 at 10 per cent load.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Hydrogen (H2) has long been recognized as an attractive fuel having excellent combustion and emissions characteristics [1, 2]. The proper burning of H2 in air produces mainly water (H2O), with a small amount of nitrogen oxides (NOx), but without fuel-sourced emissions of particulate matter (PM), hydrocarbon (HC), and carbon monoxide (CO). The absence of certain criteria pollutants and carbon dioxide (CO2) makes H2 a desirable fuel for internal combustion (IC) engines and fuel cells. Positive features of H2 as a fuel and the lingering issues blocking the wide application of H2 have been discussed in numerous publications [1–4]. For example, H2 has been recognized as a fuel having desirable combustion characteristics when burned in spark ignition (SI) engines [4]. These include low ignition energy, very fast flame propagation speed, and wide lean operational range, which make H2 a desirable alternative fuel for SI engines [4–6]. Past research on H2 as a fuel has focused on its burning in SI engines, either as a supplemental fuel to enhance the combustion process of traditional fuels such as gasoline and natural gas [1, 3–6], or as the sole fuel of dedicated lean-burn SI H2 engines [2, 7–9]. Hydrogen can also be burned in compression ignition (CI) engines using a H2–diesel dual fuel combustion mode, with H2 added into the intake air. At the end of the compression stroke, the compressed, hot H2–air mixture is ignited by a small diesel pilot. Such a dual fuel combustion mode has been considered as a reliable method of burning H2 in CI engines [10–17]. The burning of H2 as the sole fuel in CI engines was demonstrated as technically infeasible [18] due to the extremely high temperature needed for H2 to ignite through compression only.

Extensive research has been conducted to investigate the effects of H2 addition on the performance, combustion, and exhaust emissions of diesel engines. In the early decades, most of the research was conducted using small, single-cylinder diesel engines [10, 11]. For example, Varde and Frame[11] investigated the effects of H2 addition on the exhaust emissions of a single-cylinder direct injection diesel engine. The emissions of NOx were measured using a chemiluminescence analyser and reported as concentrations. The emissions of PM were inferred using a smoke meter and reported as Bosch Smoke Number (BSN). The addition of H2 was found to increase NOx emissions for the range of experiments reported by Varde and Frame [11]. In comparison, the addition of a relatively small amount of H2 reduced the emissions of PM until its minimum value was observed. Further increasing the addition of H2 was found to increase PM emissions. Tomita et al. investigated the effects of H2 addition on NOx and PM emissions using a 0.64 l, single-cylinder diesel engine [12]. The addition of H2 substantially reduced the emissions of PM measured using a smoke meter. However, the substitution of up to 70 per cent diesel by H2 had a negligible effect on NOx emissions when the engine was operated at low to medium loads with an overall equivalence ratio below 0.4. When the engine was operated at 60 per cent load with an overall equivalence ratio of 0.5, the addition of H2 increased the emissions of NOx. Saravanan and Nagarajan [13] reported a different NOx emission trend using a single-cylinder diesel engine. The substitution of 10 per cent and 20 per cent diesel with H2 increased the emissions of NOx for the overall load range examined. However, the substitution of over 30 per cent diesel by H2 reduced the emissions of NOx. This was inconsistent with the NOx emissions trend reported by other researchers [10–12], and suggests that the dual fuel combustion process may be complex.

Recently, the effect of H2 addition on the exhaust emissions has been investigated using light-duty, multi-cylinder, diesel engines with advanced diesel engine technologies including cooled exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) and common-rail fuel injection. For example, Bika et al. [14] examined the effects of H2 addition on NOx and PM emissions of a 1999 Volkswagen turbo-charged, four-cylinder, direct injection (DI) diesel engine. The substitution of up to 40 per cent diesel with H2 was reported to have only a mild effect on NOx emissions, but enhanced the conversion of nitric oxide (NO) to nitric dioxide (NO2). When measured using a Scanning Mobility Particle Sizer™ (SMPS™) spectrometer, the addition of H2 reduced both the total mass and total number of PM particles. Shirk et al. [15] examined the effects of H2 addition on the exhaust emissions of a 1.3 l, turbo-charged, four-cylinder diesel engine with a common-rail fuel system. The addition of a small amount of H2, equivalent to 5 per cent and 10 per cent of the total fuel energy, was shown to slightly reduce the emissions of NOx, while its effect on the brake thermal efficiency was small.

Following the requirements of the emissions regulations, there is increasing interest to quantify the effects of H2 addition to diesel engines with respect to total engine output, reporting the brake-specific emissions (g/bhp-hr) of HC, CO, CO2, and NOx, with the PM emissions measured using the gravimetric method. For example, Saravanan and Nagarajan [13] investigated the effects of H2 addition on PM emissions, which were reported both as a BSN and quantitatively in g/kW-hr. However, the approach used to convert PM emissions from BSN to g/kW-hr was not reported. McWilliam et al. [16] examined the effects of H2 addition, engine load, and the rate of cooled EGR on the brake-specific emissions (g/kW-hr) of NOx using a light-duty, four-cylinder diesel engine. When operated at a brake mean effective pressure (BMEP) of 2.7 bar without EGR, the addition of 6 per cent H2 (volume per cent in intake mixture) increased NOx emissions from 6.2 g/kW-hr to 19.2 g/kW-hr. With the application of 10 per cent EGR, the addition of 6 per cent H2 produced NOx emissions at a rate of 12 g/kW-hr. Compared to the addition of 6 per cent H2 without EGR, the application of 10 per cent EGR reduced NOx emissions by 37.5 per cent. Masood et al. [17] examined the effect of H2 addition on PM emissions of a single-cylinder diesel engine. The PM emissions were reported in g/m3. When operated at full load, the substitution of 90 per cent diesel with H2 was shown to reduce the PM emissions by 92.7 per cent.

Past research of H2–diesel dual fuel engines was conducted using small single-cylinder diesel engines and light-duty, multi-cylinder diesel engines. However, research of the effects of H2 addition on the exhaust emissions of heavy-duty diesel engines was not reported. The present research investigates the impact of H2 addition on the exhaust emissions of a heavy-duty diesel engine.

sec.title: 2.1 Engine and dynamometer
sec.p: The engine used was a 1999 Cummins ISM370 diesel engine. This turbo-charged, in-line, six-cylinder, heavy-duty diesel engine has been widely used in Class-8 heavy-duty trucks and certified by the United States (US) Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as having emissions at or below 4.0 g/bhp-hr NOx and 0.10 g/bhp-hr PM. Detailed specifications of the test engine are shown in Table 1. The test engine was coupled to a 550 g/kW-hr hp General Electric direct current dynamometer used to absorb the engine load and control engine speed. In this research, the torque of the engine was controlled by supplying an electronic throttle signal to the engine. With increasing addition of H2, the engine load was maintained constant by gradually reducing the amount of diesel fuel injected.

caption.p: Specifications of the test engine

sec.title: 2.2 Hydrogen fuel system
sec.p: As shown in Fig. 1, the hydrogen fuel system consisted of the following subsystems: (a) a high-pressure H2 storage and pressure regulation system used to provide H2 flow to the low-pressure H2 fuel system; (b) a low-pressure H2 flow control, metering, and delivery system designed to control and measure the flowrate of H2 and deliver it to the main stream of the intake air; and (c) a H2 safety system developed to protect the engine intake system in the event of backfire (flame arrestor shown in Fig. 1) and minimize the leak of H2 into the engine laboratory (emergency shut-down valve B shown in Fig. 1).

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the experimental set-up

sec.p: The high-pressure H2 fuel system consisted of two sets of pressure regulators, each connected to six high-pressure (150 bar) H2 cylinders. This system was used to provide H2 flow at a gauge pressure of approximately 3.2 bar. The low-pressure H2 fuel system consisted of a H2 filter, a mass flow controller (Fig. 1) for controlling and measuring the mass flowrate of H2, and a H2–air mixer manufactured in-house and used to deliver H2 continuously into the main stream of the intake air. To improve mixing of the H2 with air, the H2 mixer was installed about 2 m prior to the intake manifold and about 0.3 m prior to the flame arrestor.

The safety system consisted of a stainless steel flame arrester (Fig. 1) located between the charge air cooler and the engine intake manifold, a pressure relief valve (Fig. 1) installed between the intake manifold and the flame arrester, and two emergency shut-down valves used to completely shut down the flow of low-pressure H2 when needed. In case of backfire, the flame arrester could quench the propagation of the flame into the intake system beyond the flame arrester while the pressure relief valve could rapidly relieve the excessive pressure resulting from the burning of the H2–air mixture in the intake system. There were two emergency shut-down valves, each driven by a pneumatic actuator. The one installed after the pressure regulator was used to shut down the H2 flow from the pressure regulator to the low-pressure H2 line. The one installed prior to the H2 filter was designed to shut down the H2 flow from the low-pressure H2 line to the mass flow controller.

sec.title: 2.3 Safety operation procedures
sec.p: A series of H2 system safety operation procedures were developed and implemented in this research. These included the following. (1) A leak-free H2–fuel system designed to deliver H2 fuel to the test engine. This was achieved by a leakage inspection of the high-pressure H2 fuel system (using H2) after installation of the H2 tank, and a leakage inspection of the low-pressure H2 fuel system conducted prior to (using pressurised N2) and after the charging of the system with regulated H2 fuel. (2) The elimination of the excess H2 flowrate at the start of H2 addition. This was achieved by the control strategy of not allowing the opening of the mass flow controller prior to the opening of the H2 flow valve (emergency shut-down valve) and the detection of H2 pressure prior to the mass flow controller. (3) No sudden increase in the H2 flowrate during the switching process of engine operation modes with different H2 flowrates. The mass flow controller was programmed to gradually open when a higher H2 flowrate was requested. Additionally, no H2 was added before the set of engine operation speed and load was reached. (4) No H2 present in the low-pressure H2 fuel system after the completion of each set of experiments involving H2. This was achieved by the following approaches: (a) the H2 between the mass flow controller and mixer was consumed by continually running the engine with the mass flow controller and H2 emergency shut-down valve closed and (b) the H2 fuel trapped between the mass flow controller and pressure regulators was purged using compressed N2 after each set of experiments involving H2. After the purging of the low-pressure H2 fuel system, the pressurised N2 trapped in the H2 fuel system was used to perform the leakage test in the low-pressure H2 fuel system and serve as inertia gas when the system was recharged with low-pressure H2 prior to the next set of experiments involving H2. The latter was a very important practice to form a N2–H2 mixture other than the H2–air mixture in the low-pressure H2 fuel system during the purging and recharging process. (5) Better ventilation of the engine laboratory prior to, during, and after the completion of each set of experiments. During this research, the ceiling ventilation fans of the laboratory were used to ensure a high air exchange rate in the laboratory. After the completion of each set of experiments involving H2 and the purging of the H2 fuel system with N2, the ceiling exhaust fan was required to run for at least 30 additional minutes for further ventilation in case of possible leakage of H2 into the laboratory.

sec.title: 2.4 Exhaust emissions measurement
sec.p: The raw engine exhaust gas was ducted to a full-scale dilution tunnel with flow control accomplished using a critical flow venturi-constant volume sampler (CFV-CVS) system. A 25.4 cm diameter orifice, located 1 m from the tunnel entrance, ensured the thorough mixing of the raw exhaust gas with dilution air before reaching the dilute emissions sampling zone, located ten tunnel diameters downstream. The CFV-CVS controlled the dilute exhaust flow at a nominal 68 standard cubic metres per minute (scmm) throughout this test program. Instantaneous measurement of CFV-CVS flow was accomplished using a fast-response thermocouple and pressure transducer installed at the venturi entrance. The diluted exhaust gas was sampled from the full-flow dilution tunnel through heated sample probes, lines and finally fed into the individual emissions analysers.

The gas analysis bench was equipped with an exhaust sample conditioning and analysis system following the requirements of 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 86 Subpart N.1310-90 [19]. The emissions of CO and CO2 were measured using non-dispersive infrared (NDIR) analysers. The HC emissions were measured using a heated flame ionization detector (HFID). The emissions of NOx and NO were measured using a wet chemiluminescence system with two analysing units. One unit was equipped with an NO2 converter and was used to measure the emissions of the total NOx (including NO and NO2), while the other was without an NO2 converter and was used to measure the emissions of NO. The emissions of NO2 were calculated by subtracting NO from NOx emissions. For computational purposes, NO, NOx, and NO2 are presented in this paper as equivalent NO2 by mass, which is consistent with the calculation method recommended in the literature [19].

The PM emissions were measured using the gravimetric method. Diluted exhaust gas was drawn from the full-flow dilution tunnel into a stainless steel 10.2 cm diameter by 76.2 cm long secondary dilution tunnel and, in turn, passed through a stainless steel filter holder that contained two Pallflex 70 mm diameter model T60A20 fluorocarbon-coated glass microfibre filters in series. The sample stream was maintained at temperatures below 52 °C as measured at the inlet of the PM filter holder. Secondary dilution air, which can be used to lower the temperature of the dilute sample upstream of the sample filters, was not required during this evaluation. Prior to the measurement of PM filter mass (both before and after PM loading), sample filters were conditioned in an environmentally controlled clean room (Class 1000) with a nominal dry bulb temperature of 22 °C. The PM filters were then weighted using a Sartorius microbalance in this controlled environment. To minimize the contribution of background PM on the dilute exhaust PM measurements, dilution air was drawn through high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters located in the intake conditioning system of the full-flow dilution tunnel. The two HEPA filters, each at a 68 scmm capacity, were installed in parallel to provide up to 136 scmm.

sec.title: 2.5 Measurement of flowrate of diesel, H2, and intake air
sec.p: The flowrate of diesel fuel was measured using a Max 710 fuel flowrate measurement system. The intake air flow of the engine was measured using a laminar flow element capable of measuring the flow of air up to 27 scmm. The flowrate of H2 was controlled and measured using two compact size, digitally controlled mass flow controllers for the addition of H2 at high and low flowrates, respectively. The high-flow mass flow controller, with a capability of measuring and controlling flowrates from 10 to 1200 standard litres per minute (slpm), was used for the addition of 1–6.5 per cent H2 by volume into the intake air. The low-flow mass flow controller was used for the addition of up to 1 per cent H2 by volume into the intake air. In this study, the flow of H2 was controlled according to the engine intake air flow measured to obtain the preset H2 flow.

sec.title: 2.6 In-cylinder pressure measurement and calculation of the average bulk mixture temperature
sec.p: The in-cylinder pressure was acquired using a Kistler model 6125C pressure transducer sampled at 0.25° crank angle (CA) resolution. A low-pass filter with a cut-off frequency of 2500 Hz was applied to the raw in-cylinder pressure data to reduce the high-frequency combustion noise. The averaged cylinder bulk gas temperature was calculated using the ideal gas equation (T = PV/mR), with the measured in-cylinder pressure and cylinder volume at the intake valve closing as a reference condition. This averaged cylinder bulk gas temperature was further processed to obtain its peak value, which was used to qualitatively explain the effect of H2 addition on the variation of the peak local combustion temperature and the emissions of NOx. A detailed description of the data acquisition system and post-processing of the sampled data can be found in Liew et al. [20].

Data from exhaust analysers, sampling trains, engine instrumentation, the dynamometer, and the dilution tunnel along with flow measurements of intake air, H2, and diesel fuel, were acquired and archived at a rate of 5 Hz. Each steady-state test was performed for a duration of 270 s including 30 s of mode switching, 150 s of stabilization, and 90 s of measurement of exhaust emissions and PM sampling. Cylinder pressure was sampled over the same period of emissions measurement. Regulated emissions of HC, CO, NOx, NO, NO2, and PM were always measured and reported in brake-specific mass units. When measured using the 13-mode European Stationary Cycle (ESC), a filter-based sample of integrated PM emissions was obtained.

In this study, the effects of H2 addition on the exhaust emissions of a 1999 Cummins ISM370 engine were investigated. Initially, the effect of H2 addition on the exhaust emissions was examined using the 13-mode ESC (Table 2). For the 13-mode ESC, no H2 was added during idle mode (mode 1) due to safety concerns arising from the combustion instability that was encountered in this research. The detailed impact of H2 addition on exhaust emissions was investigated under various engine loads at 1200 r/min (Table 3). When operated under constant load, the diesel flowrate was gradually reduced with the addition of up to 6.5 per cent H2 by volume in the intake air. In this research, the maximum H2 flow was selected based on the following rules: (a) the diesel fuel flowrate at low load must be high enough to maintain stable H2–diesel dual fuel operation; (b) the maximum cylinder pressure at 70 per cent load was comparable to the peak cylinder pressure of this engine observed under maximum torque; and (c) no occurrence of engine knock was tolerable. During the H2 addition, the injection timing and injection duration of diesel fuel was allowed to shift, as managed by the engine electronic controller. However, the injection timing change was very small, as indicated by the variation of the start of combustion (SOC). When operated at 70 per cent load, the addition of 6 per cent H2 retarded the SOC by 0.8° CA. When operated at 15 per cent load, the addition of H2 had a negligible effect on the SOC. To address the feasibility of proposed small H2O electrolysers in reducing the exhaust emissions and improving the performance of diesel engines [21], the detailed effects of the addition of a very small amount of H2 (0–1 per cent in intake mixture) on the exhaust emissions were also investigated. The evaluation of H2 addition during transient operating cycles was not performed due to safety concerns and the difficulty of setting a tracking control strategy for the quantity of H2 added during transient operation.

caption.p: 13-mode emissions cycle and weighting factor
Test matrix for constant load operation

sec.title: 3.1 13-mode ESC emissions
sec.p: Table 4 shows the effect of H2 addition on the integrated emissions measured using the 13-mode ESC. The addition of 2 per cent H2 was found to increase PM emissions from 0.032 to 0.037 g/bhp-hr (+15 per cent). However, with the addition of 4 per cent H2, the PM emissions were reduced to 0.029 g/bhp-hr (−10 per cent).

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition on exhaust emissions measured using the 13-mode ESC

sec.p: As further shown in Table 4, the addition of 2 per cent H2 increased NOx emissions from 3.41 to 3.59 g/bhp-hr (+5.3 per cent). As shown in Fig. 2 for the NOx emissions obtained in each mode, the addition of 2 per cent H2 increased the emissions of NOx in all modes, with the exception of modes 9 (1580 r/min, 4.78 bar BMEP) and 11 (1887 r/min and 3.99 bar BMEP), representing the low-load operation at medium to high speeds. The addition of H2 during modes 9 and 11 was found to reduce the emissions of NOx substantially. Data shown in Fig. 2 confirm that the engine load plays an important role on the impact of H2 addition on NOx emissions.

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition on NOx emissions measured using the 13-mode ESC

sec.p: As shown in Table 4, the addition of 2 per centH2 reduced the NO emissions from 3.27 to 3.03g/bhp-hr, although the emissions of total NOx were increased by 5.3 per cent. As shown in Fig. 3, the addition of 2 per cent H2 reduced NO emissions measured at each mode with the exception of modes 6 and 8, in which the emissions of NO were not affected. The reduced NO emissions were associated with the increased emissions of NO2. As shown in Table 4, the NO2 emissions for diesel-only operation were typical and small (4.1 per cent of total NOx emissions). The addition of 2 per cent H2 substantially increased the NO2 emissions from 0.14 to 0.56 g/bhp-hr. The NO2 emissions observed with the addition of 2 per cent H2 contributed to 15.6 per cent of the total NOx emissions. Compared to baseline diesel operation, the addition of 2 per cent H2 increased NO2 emissions by 300 per cent accompanied with a reduction in NO emissions by 7.3 per cent. The increased NOx emissions (5.3 per cent) resulting from the addition of 2 per cent H2 were not enough to compensate the NO loss due to its conversion to NO2. As shown in Fig. 4, the addition of 2 per cent H2 enhanced NO2 emissions measured at all modes of the 13-mode ESC. It was evident that the addition of H2 enhanced the conversion of NO to NO2. This was consistent with the limited NO2 emissions results from prior programmes obtained using light-duty diesel engines [14, 15, 22].

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition on NO emissions measured using the 13-mode ESC
Effect of H2 addition on NO2 emissions measured using the 13-mode ESC

sec.p: As shown in Table 4, the addition of 4 per cent H2 in intake air increased NO emissions from 3.27 to 3.49 g/bhp-hr. As shown in Fig. 3, the addition of 4 per cent H2 increased NO emissions measured at each mode with the exception of modes 2, 7, 9, 11, and 13, in which the emissions of NO were reduced. However, the impact of the addition of 4 per cent H2 on NO emissions (+6.7 per cent) was much weaker than its impact on NOx emissions, which were increased from 3.41 to 3.94 g/bhp-hr (+15.5 per cent). This indicated the conversion of a large portion of NO to NO2. As shown in Fig. 4, the addition of 4 per cent H2 increased NO2 from 0.14 to 0.45 g/bhp-hr (+221 per cent). The addition of 4 per cent H2 produced much more NO2 (0.45 g/bhp-hr) than baseline diesel operation (0.14 g/bhp-hr), but less NO2 than the addition of 2 per cent H2 (0.56 g/bhp-hr). Although the addition of H2 enhanced the conversion of NO to NO2, the addition of more H2 did not necessarily produce more NO2 than the addition of a small amount of H2.

sec.title: 3.2 Constant load operation
sec.p: The detailed effect of H2 addition on the exhaust emissions was investigated under constant load operation at 1200 r/min (Table 3). With the increasing addition of H2, the flowrate of diesel fuel was gradually reduced to maintain the constant engine load. As shown in Fig. 5, the addition of up to 6.0 per cent H2 (equivalence ratio of 0.17) contributed to as much as 91 per cent of the intake energy when the engine was operated at 10 per cent load and contributed as little as 31 per cent at 70 per cent load. As shown in Fig. 6, the impact of H2 addition on the global equivalence ratio was relatively small, especially at high-load operation.

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition on diesel substitution, engine speed N = 1200 r/min, 10–70 per cent load
Effect of H2 addition on total equivalence ratio including H2 and diesel fuel, N = 1200 r/min, 10–70 per cent load

sec.title: 3.2.1 NOx, NO and NO2 emissions
sec.p: As shown in Fig. 7 for medium- to high-load operation, the addition of H2 substantially increased the emissions of NOx, especially when a large amount of H2 was added. This was consistent with published experimental data obtained using a single-cylinder small diesel engine [11] and a four-cylinder light-duty diesel engine [16]. The increased NOx emissions were due to the increased local combustion temperature resulting from the enhancement of the combustion process by H2. As shown in Fig. 8 [20], the addition of a relatively large amount of H2 substantially raised the peak heat release rate, slightly advanced the phasing at which the peak heat release rate was observed, and advanced the phasing of completion of the combustion process. Benefiting from the raised heat release rate, the addition of H2 at 30–70 per cent load reduced the combustion duration, as shown in Fig. 9 [20]. The enhanced heat release process and advanced combustion phasing increased the local combustion temperature, which enhanced the formation of NOx. As the peak local combustion temperature was not available in this research, the maximum average bulk mixture temperature calculated from cylinder pressure was employed as a surrogate, which to some extent qualitatively reflects the variation trend of the maximum local combustion temperature. As shown in Fig. 10, the addition of a small amount of H2 at 70 per cent load slightly reduced the maximum averaged bulk mixture temperature without causing an expected reduction in NOx emissions. Further increasing the addition of H2 substantially increased the maximum averaged bulk mixture temperature accompanied with a substantial increase in NOx emissions. It should be noted that the averaged bulk mixture temperature calculated was much lower than the maximum local combustion temperature due to the diffusion combustion features of diesel fuel in the H2–diesel dual fuel engine. As shown in Fig. 11 for 70 per cent load operation, the addition of a small amount of H2 slightly reduced the emissions of NO accompanied with a substantial increase in NO2 emissions. The addition of H2 beyond 2 per cent increased the emissions of both NO and NOx.

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition on NOx emissions, N = 1200 r/min, 30–70 per cent load
Effect of H2 addition on heat release rate, N = 1200 r/min, 70 per cent load [20] (ATDC: after top dead centre)
Effect of H2 addition and engine load on combustion duration, N=1200 r/min [20]
Effect of H2 addition on NOx emissions and maximum averaged bulk mixture temperature (Tmax) calculated from cylinder pressure, N = 1200 r/min, 70 per cent load
Effect of H2 addition on the emissions of NOx, NO and NO2, N = 1200 r/min, 70 per cent load

sec.p: As shown in Fig. 12 for low-load operation, the addition of a small amount of H2 (< 3 per cent) at 10 per cent load had negligible effect on NOx emissions. However, increasing the addition of H2 beyond 3 per cent was found to reduce substantially the emissions of NOx. In comparison, the addition of a small amount of H2 at 15 per cent load slightly increased NOx emissions, with the maximum NOx observed with the addition of 4 per cent H2. Further increasing the addition of H2 beyond 4 per cent substantially reduced the emissions of NOx. The dramatic drop in NOx emissions observed at 10 per cent and 15 per cent load was due to a deteriorated combustion process. As shown in Fig. 13 for 15 per cent load operation [20], the addition of a large amount of H2 significantly reduced the peak heat release rate, observed during the premixed combustion process. The first combustion peak for this H2–diesel dual fuel engine was due to the premixed combustion of diesel fuel, which was a major contribution to the formation of NOx at low-load operation. In comparison, the diffusion combustion process was slightly enhanced and elongated. This would retard the combustion event to a point later in the down-stroke and reduce the sustained local combustion temperature and the formation of NOx. The reduced maximum average bulk mixture temperature shown in Fig. 14 qualitatively confirmed the reduction of the maximum local combustion temperature. The substantial reduction in NOx emissions observed with the addition of over 4 per cent H2 was accompanied with a significant reduction in the maximum averaged bulk mixture temperature. The reduced NOx emissions could also be explained by the increased combustion duration, as shown in Fig. 9 for 15 per cent load operation [20]. The reduced peak heat release rate (Fig. 13) and increased combustion duration (Fig. 9) contributed to the reduction in the maximum local combustion temperature and the formation of NOx. In comparison, the relatively mild impact on NOx emissions of the addition of a small amount of H2 was due to the relatively mild impact of H2 on the peak heat release rate as shown in Fig. 15 [20], combustion duration (Fig. 9), and maximum average bulk mixture temperature (Fig. 14).

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition on the emissions of NOx, N = 1200 r/min, 10–20 per cent load
Effect of H2 addition on heat release rate, N = 1200 r/min, 15 per cent load [20]
Effect of H2 addition on the emissions of NOx and maximum average bulk mixture temperature, N = 1200 r/min, 15 per cent load
Effect of H2 addition and engine load on peak heat release rate [20]

sec.p: Figure 16 shows the effect of H2 addition and engine load on the NO2/NOx ratio. The addition of a small amount of H2 at low load substantially increased the NO2/NOx ratio, indicating the significant effect of H2 on the conversion of NO to NO2. The maximum NO2/NOx ratio of 62.2 per cent was observed with the addition of 4 per cent H2 at 10 per cent load. Further increasing the addition of H2 started to reduce the NO2/NOx ratio, but still produced more NO2 than for baseline diesel operation. It was also noted that the increase in engine load inhibited the enhancing impact of H2 on the NO2/NOx ratio. When operated at high load, the effect of H2 addition on the NO2/NOx ratio became weak. When operated at 70 per cent load, the maximum NO2/NOx ratio of 9.2 per cent was observed with the addition of 1 per cent H2 by volume into intake air. This could be due to the relatively high local combustion temperature, which was known to enhance the decomposition of NO2 to NO. When operated with baseline diesel, the NO2/NOx ratio observed was 2.6 per cent. The addition of H2 seems to have enhanced the conversion of NO to NO2. However, this conversion effect merits further investigation through the examination of NO2 formation chemistry.

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition and engine load on NO2/NOx ratio, N = 1200 r/min, 10–70 per cent load

sec.title: 3.2.2 Particulate matter emissions
sec.p: As shown in Fig. 17 for medium- to high-load operation, the addition of up to 4.5 per cent H2 gradually reduced the emissions of PM. A further increase of H2 beyond 4.5 per cent had only minimal reduction effect on PM emissions. As shown in Fig. 18, the addition of up to 4.5 per cent H2 for low-load operation gradually reduced PM emissions as well. However, the addition of H2 beyond 4.5 per cent started to increase PM emissions, especially at 10 per cent load. Compared to diesel operation, the maximum PM reduction obtained was 40 per cent and 65 per cent, which was obtained when operated at 10 per cent and 70 per cent load, respectively. It was also demonstrated that the reduction in PM emissions was mainly due to the reduction in diesel fuel flowrate. As shown in Fig. 19, the addition of H2 had a minor effect on the fuel specific PM emissions rate, defined as the PM emissions per kg of diesel fuel burned. As shown in Fig. 19 for medium- to high-load operation, the addition of H2 had a mild impact on the fuel specific PM emissions rate reported in g/kgdiesel, especially at 50 per cent and 70 per cent load. The reduction in PM emissions at medium to high load was due to the reduced diesel fuel flowrate rather than the significantly improved combustion of diesel fuel. As shown in Fig. 20, the addition of a relatively small amount of H2 at low load had a mild effect on PM emissions evaluated on diesel fuel flow basis. However, the addition of a relatively large amount of H2 substantially increased the fuel specific PM emissions, especially at 10 per cent load. This unexpected increase in PM emissions observed with the addition of a relatively large amount of H2 at low load (Fig. 18) was due to the incomplete combustion of diesel fuel. This might be due to the poorer atomization of diesel fuel when injected in a very short pulse and the reduced temperature combustion at low load. When operated at 10 per cent load, the diesel fuel flowrate observed at 6 per cent H2 addition was about 9 per cent of baseline diesel operation. The diesel fuel injected during initiation and ending of the injection event contributes to a greater proportion of the fuel delivered at light load, and may offer a suboptimal spray pattern. In addition, part of the diesel fuel might have been mixed with the hot combustion products of H2 during the diffusion combustion process of diesel fuel, which might have contributed to the increased PM emissions observed. The addition of H2 to the diesel engine did not reduce the PM emissions through the improved combustion of diesel fuel.

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition on PM emissions, N = 1200 r/min, 30–70 per cent load
Effect of H2 addition on PM emissions, N = 1200 r/min, 10–20 per cent load
Effect of H2 addition on diesel fuel specific PM emissions, N = 1200 r/min, 30–70 per cent load
Effect of H2 addition on diesel fuel specific PM emissions, N = 1200 r/min, 10–20 per cent load

sec.title: 3.2.3 HC and CO emissions
sec.p: As shown in Fig. 21, the addition of H2 reduced the emissions of CO with the exception of the 70 per cent load case. However, the addition of up to 3.5 per cent H2 at 70 per cent load had negligible effect on CO emissions. Further increasing the addition of H2 beyond 4 per cent slightly increased the emissions of CO. As shown in Fig. 22, the addition of H2 at medium to high loads (30–70 per cent load) has a negligible effect on HC emissions. However, the addition of a large amount of H2 (beyond 5 per cent) at 10–20 per cent load slightly increased the emissions of HC. This might be due to the incomplete atomization observed when the diesel fuel flowrate was very low. The diesel fuel injected during initiation and ending of the injection event was usually not well atomized. When the flowrate of diesel fuel was extremely low, the diesel fuel injected during initiation and ending of the injection event contributed to a significant portion of the total fuel injected. This might explain to some extent the increased PM (Fig. 18), CO (Fig. 21), and HC emissions (Fig. 22) observed with the addition of a large amount of H2 at low load.

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition on CO emissions, N = 1200 r/min, 10–70 per cent load
Effect of H2 addition on HC emissions, N = 1200 r/min, 10–70 per cent load

sec.p: As shown in Fig. 23, the addition of a large amount of H2 did not significantly affect the combustion stability represented by the coefficient of variation (COV) in the indicated mean effective pressure (IMEP). The increased PM (Figs 18 and 20), CO (Fig. 21), and HC (Fig. 22) emissions observed at low load with the addition of a large amount of H2 were not due to the unstable combustion of this dual fuel engine operation.

caption.p: Effect of H2 addition on COV in IMEP, N = 1200 r/min, 15 and 70 per cent load

sec.title: 4 Conclusions
sec.p: The addition of a relatively large amount of H2 at medium to high loads substantially increased the emissions of NOx. In comparison, the addition of a small amount of H2 had mild effects on the emissions of NOx. The substantial reduction of NOx emissions was only observed with the addition of a relatively large amount of H2 at 10–15 per cent load. When measured using the 13-mode ESC, the addition of 2 per cent and 4 per cent H2 increased the emissions of NOx by 5.3 per cent and 15.5 per cent, respectively.

The addition of H2 enhanced the conversion of NO to NO2. When measured using the 13-mode ESC, the addition of 2 per cent and 4 per cent H2 increased the NO2 emissions by 300 per cent and 221 per cent, respectively. When examined at constant load, the maximum NO2/NOx ratio of 62.2 per cent was observed at 10 per cent load, with the addition of 4 per cent H2 by volume into intake air. When operated at 70 per cent load, the maximum NO2/NOx ratio of 9.2 per cent was observed with the addition of 1 per cent H2.

The addition of H2 substantially reduced PM emissions reported in g/bhp-hr. With the addition of up to 6 per cent H2, maximum PM reductions of 40 per cent and 65 per cent were observed when the engine was operated at 10 per cent and 70 per cent load, respectively. The reduction in PM emissions was mainly due to the reduced consumption of diesel fuel.

The addition of a large amount of H2 at low load increased the fuel specific PM emissions reported in g/kgdiesel. In comparison, the addition of H2 at medium to high load had a mild impact on fuel specific PM emissions. The addition of H2 did not necessarily reduce the PM emissions through the improved combustion of diesel fuel.

The addition of H2 substantially reduced CO emissions with the exception of the 70 per cent load operation. When operated at 70 per cent load, the addition of a large amount of H2 slightly increased CO emissions. In comparison, the addition of H2 had a negligible effect on HC emissions when operated at medium to high loads (30–70 per cent). The addition of H2 at low loads (10–20 per cent) increased HC emissions.

fn.p: This work was supported by the State of Texas [contract number HARC NTRD N-44] through a grant from the Texas Environmental Research Consortium, with funding provided by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.
